Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Novel Process Technology for Point-of-Generation Nitrogen Removal from Wastewater
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to address the grand challenge of human-induced nitrogen loading to the environment. An easy-to-use and affordable system will target a major source of nitrogen releases to watersheds: the on-site systems that treat wastewater from millions of households and commercial facilities across the U.S. The need to mitigate harmful algal blooms and prevent other damaging cumulative effects to aquatic ecosystems have created an urgent demand for onsite technologies that remove nitrogen at its source. The proposed nitrogen removal technology is modular and adaptable for use in small-scale systems that treat wastewater from individual homes, community systems and commercial establishments. The project employs an innovative biological nitrogen removal process that that will be verified and optimized for high priority applications in rural, peri-urban, and urban settings. The system is mechanically simple, generates no waste products, and operates passively with minimal maintenance, energy or consumables. The results from this project will help to solve the critical challenge of nitrogen control by providing a highly efficient, low-cost, commercializable system that is practicable for on-site wastewater treatment in new and retrofit systems.

The technical objectives of this Phase I research project are to design, construct, field-test, and critically evaluate variant prototypes of an innovative bioreactor system to remove nitrogen from onsite wastewater. Prototype bioreactors will be operated and monitored over multiple months to investigate their salient operational characteristics and define effective design and treatment regimes. The bioreactors will be installed to treat real household wastewater under field conditions. Nitrogen analytes will be monitored across the bioreactor systems to delineate the effects of biotreatment on four nitrogen species: organic nitrogen, ammonium, nitrate and nitrite. The effects of the biotreatment system on chemical and biochemical oxygen demand, inorganic chemical parameters, and other wastewater constituents of interest will also be elucidated. The project will critically evaluate the effectiveness of total nitrogen removal and the stability and resiliency of individual nitrogen removal transformations. The work will confirm the longevity and robustness of the nitrogen removal process and identify design and operating parameters that optimize an innovative approach to remove total nitrogen from on-site wastewater while mitigating nitrogen releases to the environment. Prototype design and monitoring will facilitate scale-up of results to full-scale biotreatment systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Novel Process Technology for Point-of-Generation Nitrogen Removal from Wastewater

NSF Award: 1621647

Reliable, low-cost, easy-to-use treatment systems for reducing nitrogen pollution can revolutionize water resource protection. This project focuses on a historically overlooked source of nitrogen releases to the environment: the on-site wastewater treatment systems that process 25% of domestic/household wastewater in rural, semi-rural, and peri-urban areas across the U.S. The nitrogen removal technology developed in this SBIR project is a flexible and scalable system that can be tailored to accommodate a variety of site conditions and treatment scenarios. This project demonstrated the feasibility of operating a small-footprint nitrogen removal technology with minimal energy inputs and simple maintenance requirements. It laid the groundwork for further technology development that can foster widespread adoption to control nitrogen releases in watersheds that are vulnerable to excess nitrogen pollution, recurring algal blooms, and eutrophication.

The nitrogen removal system tested in this project consists of simple, single-pass, porous media biofilters containing granular cation-exchange media. The biofilters serve to convert wastewater nitrogen to dinitrogen (N2) using naturally occurring microorganisms, without the need for supplemental electron donors. The use of cation-exchange media in the biofilters provides a novel approach to mediate the non-steady conditions that are characteristic of onsite wastewater systems. Cation-exchange media adds stability, resiliency, and reliability by intermittent ammonium sequestration. The design of this biofilter fosters a multi-step process to convert ammonium ion (NH4+) to N2. In the first step, which requires oxygen, NH4+ is converted by aerobic microorganisms to nitrite (NO2-). Nitrite can then be transformed by several different reactions in the biofilter, depending on the availability of dissolved oxygen (O2) and organic carbon. High oxygen levels favor conversion of nitrite to nitrate (NO3-) by oxygen-requiring microorganisms. Low oxygen levels are more suitable to another set of microorganisms that convert nitrite to N2 using ammonium (anammox). Still another set of microorganisms convert nitrite and nitrate to N2 using organic carbon (denitrification).

In this project, a suite of bench-scale bioreactors were tested to optimize oxygenation designs and oxygen supply regimes. Two methods of oxygen supply were tested: non-dispersive submerged oxygenation using dense membranes and porous membranes, and submerged porous tubes and plates. It was possible to reduce up to 81% of the Total Nitrogen and 99% of ammonia nitrogen in the wastewater streams. The technology achieved an ammonia nitrogen reduction of 62 mg/L with limited nitrate accumulation. The promising results of bench-scale testing are an important step towards developing simple, low-cost nitrogen-removing biofilters using readily available materials and naturally occurring microorganisms. This research confirmed the underlying scientific principles of nitrogen removal and provided operating experience with a new low-cost onsite nitrogen removal technology. The project sets the stage for detailed design and field verification of full-scale systems and for commercialization strategies that control nitrogen releases from on-site treatment systems across the US and globally.
